"The big money people have made it even more difficult for the kids of low wage families to get those needed educations today."
This isn't entirely true because you have to factor in the 25% of kids that drop out of high school, and only a part of the remaining 75% want to go to college. Maybe 25% and of those Only 50% of those who go to college complete the course. There is way too much talk about college and expenses etc. 1 in 4 have a college diploma and what percent of those are really worth the paper it is printed on? My father went back to college after he retired and got his diploma, that is how much education meant to him, but then he was born in 1909, when finishing high school was a big deal. People simply don't have that feeling today. They have the INTERNET when they need information. Why bother with school?
We need plans for a real society, not some utopia. We need people with real skills to perform REAL jobs--the problem is that there are no REAL jobs--even if you graduate for college. College graduates, by and large, are NOT union members ( with some exceptions). The days of toil have largely left us what with machines and all.
We need a voice from on high to tell what the jobs of tomorrow will be, where they will be and how much they will pay. Then maybe people will want education. Until then, why bother with school only to get into debt?
Which explains why education, along with healthcare, has seen the steepest rise in costs of any "commodity" in our society.

In the 1930s workers formed unions and went on strike for better working conditions, and better pay. The labor force at GM had a sit down strike that shut the company down. That resulted in pensions, overtime pay, medical plans, holidays, the 40 hour week. Before them the garment workers became organized after the Shirtwaist Triangle fire in 1911 killed 146 young immigrant ladies. Ford hired thugs to beat union organizers, and some were killed. Even so, the great majority of the work force were willing to stand up to these satraps.

Today, we see the disintegration of the unions, and those hard earned benefits. Although it is the wealthy managers, led on by the MBAs that are stopping these benefits, it is the workers who will not stand up to them now. We see these large corporations locating to southern states where the workers are anti union, and are willing to work for just enough to get by.
We have seen the work force divided against each other, and that has been the strategy of the corporations. Money makes money, and that means power. Until these workers learn just how they are being used, that is how they will live.

The immigrants of the early 1900s sent their kids to schools, to become professionals and get ahead, because they came from societies that valued education.

The big money people have made it even more difficult for the kids of low wage families to get those needed educations today.

The real issue is not that inequality exists, but why do so many millions at lower incomes refuse to believe it?

The millions of middle-class and even lower income people that refuse to believe there is an inequality problem are followers of a new type of patriotic religion. They have been sold a bill of goods by conservatives (most with boatloads of money) that taxation, regulation, and anything that restricts or redirects commercial activity is a violation of what it is to be an American. The core of patriotism is rooted in hyper-individualism where people can do whatever they want with abandon, so long as it makes them more money. You will have just as much luck getting a devout Christian to believe that Jesus was just an ordinary man as you will getting these people to believe that inequality exists or is even a bad thing.

Then the right wing machine tells the true believers that any information to the contrary is made by those out to destroy us by spreading false information to further their twisted ways. This insulates the believers from learning the truth. Evolution wars are a good example of how this works. The deal is sealed by blaming "those other people" for any inequality and portraying solutions as just stealing from the believers.

Their own suffering is insufficient to convince just as many have been willing to suffer and even die for their religion.

So the battle must be fought by replacing belief with reality. Good luck with that.

The Professor's rhetorical device of "income inequality" implies a causality between skyrocketing upper incomes and stagnating lower and middle class incomes. Skyrocketing wealth is aestetically and socially unappealing, but that does not mean it is causing or even correlated to the stagnating lower and middle class incomes. Focussing on it keeps our eyes off the real goal: raising the income and economic contributions of the lower and middle classes. Taking wealth or income away from the wealthy (while a valid political or social agenda for its own sake) will not help the poor or middle class.

Of course most of the 1% and 5% do not deserve their new-found wealth and have a proclivity for boorish self-centered conduct. So what? How does pointing that out help the rest of America. Give us some real solutions Professor!

1% take nearly 25% of income every year.
1% control 40% of the wealth of the nation.

The 400 richest Americans have $2 trillion or $2,000,000,000,000.
If this $2 trillion was spread over the current labor force of 154,937,000 that would give each person the sum of $12,908.

400 persons is about .00013% of the total population.
These persons make up .00026% of the labor force.

$400,000,000,000 billion or one-fifth (1/5) of $2 trillion ($2,000,000,000,000) is held by just 10 persons.
Two families - Koch and Walton - make up 6 of those 10 persons.
Koch (2) have $72 billion ($72,000,000,000) and Walton (4) have $136 billion ($136,000,000,000).

If their combined fortunes were spread over the current work force each person would have $1342.

Taking the other 4 persons with $192 billion and spreading this sum over the current work force would give each person another $1239.

By all means check the math and get back to me, inasmuch as it is 2 am in the morning - my time.
We are dealing with quite a few zeros here - both numeric and human.

I have fiddled around with this exercise because I deplore the mathematically challenged condition that pervades our society.
Grasping magnitude is never easy, but we should all strive to gain this numeric capability.

I wonder how far into space a pile of $2 trillion one dollar bills would stretch toward the stars above.
Any takers? I look forward to any and all reports.

Our economy has grown steadily through the whole period. Incomes have stagnated or fallen for all but a few. Those few took it all.

That is how much it matters, for the last thirty years and more.

While a lot of it is technically stock that can be sold for cash in the stock market, the real value lies in the companies that stock represents. It's a bunch of buildings, computer systems, vehicles, stock in trade, and employees, not a pile of $100 bills.

That means, essentially, that it can't be spent - unless you sold all the physical assets in the US to foreigners. The $12K that each person would get would provide a tiny flow of cash income, about $300-400 a year. So they would probably just sell it and spend the money. Sell it to who? Paul -- I have a question for you. I don't know the answer to this, and I haven't learned the answer from your columns. But I do think it's a question that's worth knowing the answer to.

The question has to do with how much the rising incomes of the 0.1 percent actually matter. For the same of argument, suppose you confiscated the entire annual income of the top 0.1 percent, and redistributed it to the bottom 99 percent, prorating it so that everyone's income rises by the same amount. What would that amount be? Would my annual income rise by 5 percent? 50 percent? 100 percent? If the number is small, then the very rich aren't taking that much away from the rest of us in absolute terms, even if they are outstripping us percentage-wise. But if the number is large, then maybe there really is a problem.

This seems like it ought to be a fairly straightforward calculation, and the result would be a something that people could readily understand and remember. So can you tell us what the number is?

Well, it's true that the income gains have gone to the top 1% or even the top 0.1% but this article doesn't address the causes of the "winner take all" society we've become. "Affluent people are affluent in part because they made the right choices."

Read the article. No, that is not it.

Affluent people are affluent in part because they made the right choices. Stable home lives, hard work, earning a good education, and choosing high-paying careers do lead to financial success. Absent a special talent, those basic life choices are more or less prerequisites to get to the top 10 or 20 percent of wage earners--even for children of the 10 to 20 percent. My wife and I both come from top 10 percent families and we're the only two of the children to have made it there ourselves. However, Dr Krugman said, obtaining a spot in the ranks of the extremely rich is different, requiring the correct parents, a special talent, or successful rent-seeking.

The problem with poverty is that regardless of why it exists, the poor are poor. The question is what to do about it. It's easy to believe the solution is higher marginal tax rates on the rich or eliminating the carried interest loophole. While both (or at least the second) may be great ideas, they won't solve poverty.

Solving poverty certainly requires opportunity. Starting with fully funding state schools would help. Infrastructure projects could help provide opportunities that don't require college degrees. I would love to pay higher taxes for both. Solving the other challenges surrounding poverty is much harder. How do you create expectations for children different from the lives of their parents? No idea here.

I think you missed the part where Professor Krugman said PUBLIC colleges. In public colleges, as opposed to institutions like Princeton that have extremely wealthy benefactors, there has been a draining of funding. In addition, there has been ample documentation of salaries at public colleges and universities declining, which includes the rise of adjunct professors that have no benefits. That covers your first and third points.

I really don't understand your second point. The only response I have to that is society benefits when there is a better educated citizenry. Having wealthier people subsidize that makes sense. Unless you think it is better to have more people on the welfare rolls.

"I simply do not see that it might anytime soon in the USA, if ever."

Such events come suddenly without warning, seemingly from nowhere.

It happened when the Soviet Union collapsed.

It will happen when North Korea collapses.

It was greeted and cheered by the population. We forget that because of what it became, what happened after, and the writing of that history by the victors. Should the scientific enterprise carry its fidelity to the process to humans' demise. Kind of sounds like religion to me.

America is harsh on its young. Too harsh.

It is a well-known fact that the human brain develops into the mid-twenties. Young people make mistakes, all over the planet. In America, they pay for those mistakes over their lifetime, with a criminal record that will bar them from most of the things that make individuals successful in their communities.

Congress, if we ever elect a sane one again, should make it its business to enact laws that move us away from a lifetime of punishment for young criminals. It should definitely make it a law that no state shall treat a child as an adult. Congress should also move states away from feeding the school to prison pipeline and offer incentives for the kind of positive reinforcement and rehabilitation that can and will push the young back on a track of success. By positive reinforcement, I including expunging the records of previously incarcerated individual for non-violent offenses, with the completion of their parole requirements, for example.

We desperately need to put a bright light at the end of the tunnel and stop condemning people for eternity as we do.
And that's only the abbreviated list of his shortcomings.

Is this admonition coming from the man who falsely claimed to have won a Nobel Prize; who does not recognize the Medieval Warm period despite overwhelming proxy and archeological evidence; and was criticized by the National Academy of Sciences for not making his data sets and methods readily available to his peers? Yep, that's our Mann and our NYT's in their new era of being the FOX News of the left. Biased till blind.

MIchael B.,
Unfortunately you're correct that some scientists do their paymaster's bidding. I don't think that's most of them, but all it takes is some to sow confusion and endless but meaningless debate. And yes, some consulting firms make a living that way. Some of that is the fault of "media balance" and the desire to find contrasting opinions in every news story. Some of it is because we only really want to hear things that we agree with, and so seek opinions that line up with our preconceived notions. Science is important in many areas, and so it makes perfect sense that it (in part) becomes a service. That doesn't mean it has to be biased, but it might be. Its a good idea to look at who has funded some work, but there is a very unfortunate tendency to dismiss a priori any work that has been funded by anybody who may have an interest in the outcome. The recent EDF study on gas leakage iso one example. A lot of people who didn't like the outcome wanted to dismiss it out of hand because it had industry funding, regardless of how the study was conducted. That's just foolishness, akin to saying we won't take the Sistine Chapel seriously because Michelangelo was paid by the Pope. So, people should be aware, but not be so reflexively cynical that they ignore good work dimly on the basis of guilt by association.

I teach American history at a mid-sized public university in Tennessee and explain the difference between "the deserving poor" and the "undeserving poor" as an artifact of a bygone age with values the modern era has surpassed and improved upon.  I can only conclude we are indeed moving back to a new Gilded Age because some of my students find the old distinction perfectly valid for the 21st century.  I'm at a loss how to respond.  But the notion of "undeserving poor" has been revived and publicized by the wealthy and their media spokespersons because it legitimizes both the notion that the government can do nothing, and that low taxes are the road to salvation for all of us.

replies.commentBody: So, JD, suppose Mann et al 1998 had never even been published?  What then?  Would all of the other evidence and the many, many other papers on climate change suddenly "go away"?  And Dyson?  Are you kidding?   Simple calculations about climate change have been around for well over a century. Arrhenius (1890's), Hurlbut, and then Callendar (1930's) got basically the same result as fancy modern models for climate sensitivity to CO2.  This is an exercise one can do with numerically literate freshman.  So, should we assume that all the many physicists, mathematicians, chemist, biologists, engineers etc who have worked on this problem are in fact clueless about math and statistics, and we should all instead trust a guy with a BS in math and some unpublished experience in the mining industry to get it all right for us?  And then they got a PhD statistician to back him up and it turned out he wrote an article so badly plagiarized (from one of Mann's coauthors, no less) it was withdrawn by the journal?

comments.commentBody:
Derry: " Scientists are generally pretty good with data and numbers,"

If I hadn't seen your previous posts, I would consider this statement a joke. Michael Mann's statistical incompetence has been demonstrated on many occasions by Steve McIntyre, including the Tiljander fiasco.

In 2013 McIntyre commented: "One of the longstanding CA criticisms of paleoclimate articles is that scientists with little-to-negligible statistical expertise too frequently use ad hoc and homemade methods in important applied articles, rather than proving their methodology in applied statistical literature using examples other than the one that they’re trying to prove.
Marcott’s uncertainty calculation is merely the most recent example. "
See link http://climateaudit.org/2013/04/07/marcotts-dimple-a-centering-artifact/
Also, Freeman Dyson has demonstrated that Hansenite climate models are grossly inadequate. See http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=985641c9-8594-43c2...

JD

This seems a bit of an invented controversy.  The notion that science is some kind of simple list of “facts” is not, never has been, and never will be true.  Interpretation and judgment about data and theory is a critical part of science.  The idea that there is some strict separation between “science” and “policy” is a false dichotomy.  What makes someone a “policy expert” anyway?  Implicit in any choice of political or economic policy are values and judgments. I have yet to see the policy analyst who’s views aren’t influenced by his/her values.  I agree with Ken that it’s important not to make a big pitch on an issue unless you have done your homework.  As he points out, too many people pontificate on subjects about which they have cursory knowledge (I could go on about some physicists and climate).  But any scientist willing to put in the work can be a perfectly good advocate for policy.  Scientists are generally pretty good with data and numbers, and those skills can indeed translate usefully into the policy realm.  So much of what passes for policy debate is sufficiently devoid of any real constraints that a more “scientific” approach can only be an improvement.  I quite agree with Michael, more scientists need to step up.  There isn’t a thing wrong with proposing or advocating policy as a scientist as long as you have taken some time to inform yourself and have something both reasoned and reality based to say.

If you want to complain about the politicization of a neutral scientific fact (ACC) look no further than below:

"Conservative billionaires used a secretive funding route to channel nearly $120m (£77m) to more than 100 groups casting doubt about the science behind climate change, the Guardian has learned.

The funds, doled out between 2002 and 2010, helped build a vast network of thinktanks and activist groups working to a single purpose: to redefine climate change from neutral scientific fact to a highly polarising "wedge issue" for hardcore conservatives."

I'd say the conservative thinktanks have been highly successful.

You could try looking at the science and records rather than repeating memes provided to distract and deceive, for starters. 200 years of science and a startlingly large majority of credible science demonstrate that this kind of obfuscation is political.

Nature bats last, and it bats 1000. Wake up please!

There are many records of the levels of CO2 and temperatures (based on the ratios of different oxygen isotopes) in the past, including the exo- and endoskeletons of many extant and ancient organisms, but probably the most immediate ones are ice cores of ancient ice in regions like Antarctica. You should study the science before deciding if you agree or not with it, otherwise you would only be making an appeal from ignorance.

A comment on an op-ed dated Feb. 10, 2007, captures an agnostic view of belief in Mann-made global warming=climate change (excerpts only due to character limits):

“Of course, like Katrina, global warming has been almost totally politicized, thus making it very difficult to separate substance from “spin”--in emanations from "scientists" as well as in those from newspaper columnists and editors (whose inevitably biased opinions tend to dictate the assembly and presentation on the front page of what is likely to be perceived (by the naive) as "unadorned reality". In the case of "Katrina", for example, the immediate, unrelenting, politically oriented, non-substance related, Bush-blaming (that continues to this very day) tended to drown the natural surge of sympathy that tends to follow all such tragic occurrences in a tidal wave of political animus.

“In the case of man-made global warming, absent confirmation a la Einstein, there is no way on earth to know who is "right" or "wrong", hence it is an arena that is ripe for, and rife with, political/social/scientific/media hucksterism. (That Algore has become active in the arena is sufficient to make the latter point) . . ..” (end excerpt).

And even today, journalists tend to say things that reinforce doubt, e.g., as in the column under consideration: ". . . CO2 levels in the atmosphere exceed those observed(sic) for at least the last 650,000 years . . .." Observed? By whom and how? And where are the observations stored?

The NYT is in the middle of its own puzzle, as are we all. If one pays sufficient attention to climate change, everything changes. (Even if one just reads the articles about it in the NYT.) Example -- the NYT still has a travel section promoting 52 places to go, a lovely idea. On the other hand, "Your Biggest Carbon Sin May Be Air Travel:" http://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/27/sunday-review/the-biggest-carbon-sin-a...

http://qz.com/129477/why-im-never-flying-again/

But for now, presumably, the travel section needs to stay just to pay for the excellent journalism that will tell us why the travel section is a mistake.
